comms: Not included in the database because X is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
back_translation_en: ‘I have a headache,’ lit. ‘My head aches.’
comms_internal: Y-u X metti is an intransitive construction with the complex NP Y-u X in subject function, lit. ‘X’s Y aches’ (-u marks the head noun in the genitival construction). X can also be expressed as a possessive determiner.

back_translation_en: ‘Which sickness does he suffer from?’, lit. ‘Which sickness invaded him?’
comms_internal: This is a transitive construction with the name of the sickness in subject role, lit. ‘Sickness invades person’. I am aware of no possibility of expressing the same meaning by means of a construction with the name of the person affected by the sickness in subject role.

sentence: l-i ñu ma may doy na ma
glosses_en: clL-REL sI:3PL oI:1SG give satisfy PRF.sI:3SG oI:1SG
back_translation_en: ‘What they gave me is enough for me,’ lit. ‘What they gave me satisfies me.’
comms_internal: ‘What they gave me is enough for me.’ lit. ‘What they gave me satisfies me.’

sentence: Omar dafa bëgg-a mel ni Sàmba
glosses_en: PN FocV.sI:3SG want-AUX resemble like PN
comms_internal: Alternative is “niru” with the TR pattern, cf. “golo ñaaw-ul baay b-a la niru” [monkey(G) be.ugly-PERF.NEG.sI:3SG father(B) clB-DEF.DIST FocO/X.sI:3SG resemble] ‘The monkey is not ugly, it resembles its father.’ There is no specific reason for choosing the option with “mel” except that this is an intransitive pattern and the fact that Denis mentioned that “there are many more examples with mel in Diouf’s dictionary, which is the most detailed dictionary of Wolof.”
Alternative is fab with the same valency pattern.

back_translation_en: ‘I saw your mother at the market.’

sentence: sa-y at dafa-y am njeexital ci sa xel
glosses_en: POSS:2SG-clY year(M) FocV.sI:3SG-INCPL have end(L) LOC POSS:2SG mind(M)
back_translation_en: ‘Age influences memory,’ lit. ‘Your years have an end on your mind.’
comms_internal: CV. Alternatives are “wàllsi” and “feeñ” with the same valency structure.

sentence: tase naa ak moom mu jëm marse
glosses_en: meet PRF.sI:1SG with 3SG sI:3SG head.towards market(B)
back_translation_en: ‘I met him/her (accidentally), s/he was heading towards the market.’
comms_internal: DC: Wolof ak corresponds both to English with and and. Note that in the X ak Y tase variant, the verb can only express plural agreement, whereas in the X tase ak Y variant, the verb agrees with X. All semantically reciprocal verbs behave in the same way as tase, cf. 23, 24, 32, 64, 84, 98, 99.

sentence: jaan j-i dugg na ci pax m-i
glosses_en: snake(J) clJ-DEF enter PRF.sI:3SG LOC hole(M) clM-DEF

comms_internal: This verb also means ‘fell’. Alternatives are gañe (from French gagner, it means specifically ‘win’), as well as dóor and duma, which also mean ‘hit’.

back_translation_en: ‘I am getting out of the car.’
comms_internal: APPL. The verb génne is an applicative verb derived from génn ‘go out’.

back_translation_en: ‘Who drove the cows to the pasture yesterday?’
comms_internal: The verb faral is a transitive verb used exclusively with reference to cattle. Another transitive verb (dàq) is used to express the other meanings that can be rendered as chase in English.
CAUS. This verb is derived from intransitive sëgg ‘become bent’.

sentence: Gaynde ne y-eneen rab y-i gan g-i nit la
glosses_en: PN tell clY-other animal(W) clY-DEF stranger(G) clG-DEF person(K/Ñ) EqCOP
back_translation_en: ‘Gaynde (Lion) told the other animals: –The stranger is a human being.’
comms_internal: Wolof also has a verb wax ‘say’, which differs from ne in the following two respects: it cannot introduce directly a reported utterance, but it can be found in a double-object construction.

sentence: xale b-i dafa ŋàbb a-b téere
glosses_en: child(B) clB-DEF FocV.sI:3SG hold INDEF-clB book(B)
back_translation_en: ‘The child is holding a book in his hands.’

sentence: Usmaan dab na ma ci yoon w-i
glosses_en: PN catch.up PRF.sI:3SG oI:1SG LOC road(W) clW-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘Usmaan caught me up on the road.’

sentence: sàmm b-i angi-y ratt nag w-i
glosses_en: herdsman(B) clB-DEF PRST-INCPL milk cow (W) clW-DEF

comms_internal: Alternative is “jot” with the TR pattern, cf. “jot-ag-unu tefes g-i” [reach-NONDUM-PRF.NEG.sI:1PL shore(G) clG-DEF] ‘We haven’t reached the shore yet.’ The reason for choosing the option with “àgg” is that it is intransitive and also “expresses specifically the spatial sense, whereas jot has a much wider meaning” (The transitive verb jot co-expresses ‘reach’ and ‘receive’.) According to one of the consultants, with àgg, the locative preposition can be dropped.

comms: Context: a person is butchering an animal.
sentence: wextan wi dafa laal yàpp wi
glosses_en: bile(W) clW-DEF FocV.sI:3SG touch meat(W) clW-DEF

comms_internal: Xaritoo is a reciprocal verb derived from the noun xarit ‘friend’.

Alternatives are takku and wekku, also used with the SBJ_ci pattern. Aju ‘depend on’ is probably a metaphorical use of aju ‘be placed in a high place’, derived from aj ‘place in a high place’ via middle derivation. Takku ‘depend on’ is a metaphorical use of takku ‘be tied’, derived from takk ‘tie’ via middle derivation. Wékku ‘depend on’ is a metaphorical use of wékku ‘hang (intr.)’, derived from wékk ‘hang (tr.)’ via middle derivation.
The intransitive reciprocal verb xamante derives from transitive xam ‘know’, cf. 33.
The transitive verb tëgg co-expresses ‘play (a musical instrument)’ and ‘forge (a metallic object)’.

sentence: k-u nekk ci xare war-ul-a ree k-u ñu jam
glosses_en: clK-REL be LOC battle(B) must-PRF.NEG.sI:3SG-AUX make.fun clK-REL sI:3PL wound
back_translation_en: ‘A person engaged in a battle should not make fun of a person who has been wounded.’
comms_internal: ree is also used intransitively with the meaning ‘laugh’ (monovalent).

This is a transitive construction, but am is also used in a transimpersonal construction with an expletive 3rd person singular subject index with the meaning ‘there is’, and intransitively with the meaning ‘exist’.

back_translation_en: ‘It was me who painted his house.’
comms_internal: Like English paint, pintiir is both a noun and a transitive verb. Its origin is the French noun peinture.

sentence: xaj b-i dafa màtt xale b-i
glosses_en: dog(B) clB-DEF FocV.sI:3SG bite child(B) clB-DEF
comms_internal: The verb màtt is among the transitive verbs of Wolof that require antipassive derivation to be used in an unspecified object construction: “xaj b-ii dafa-y màtt-e” [dog(B) clB-DEM FocV.sI:3SG-INCPL bite-ANTIP] ‘This dog bites.’

sentence: ñàkk nga sa xaalis ci dara
glosses_en: lose PRF.sI:2SG POSS:2SG money(B) LOC nothing
comms_internal: Same as 56, same verb as 82. The verb ñàkk is also used transitively with the stative meaning ‘lack’, cf. 56, and intransitively with the meaning ‘lose to someone’, cf. 82. The lexeme ñàkk is also used as an auxiliary verb ‘fail to do something’, and as a noun with the meaning ‘lack of something’.

sentence: alkaati b-i dafa-y jéem-a jàpp sàcc b-i
glosses_en: policeman(B) clB-DEF FocV.sI:3SG-INCPL try-AUX catch thief(B) clB-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘The policeman is trying to catch the thief.’
comms_internal: CV. The meaning ‘try to catch’ can only be expressed by combining jàpp ‘catch’ with the auxiliary jéem ‘try’.

back_translation_en: ‘I broke the legg of the chair.’

sentence: dafa la-y jay te sa xaalis a tax
glosses_en: FocV.sI:3SG oI:2SG-INCPL flatter and POSS:2SG money(B) FocS cause
back_translation_en: ‘He flatters you, and it’s because of your money.’

sentence: xale b-i yëngal na bant b-i
glosses_en: child(B) clB-DEF wave PRF.sI:3SG stick(B) clB-DEF
comms_internal: Same as 109. The transitive verb yêngal means more generally ‘move’. It forms an equipollent noncausal-causal pair with yëngu ‘move (intr.).

sentence: Usmaan bëgg na lool daamar g-u bees
glosses_en: PN want PRF.sI:3SG very.much car(G) clG-REL be.new
back_translation_en: ‘Usmaan is dreaming of a new car.’
comms_internal: CV. In Wolof, the verb gént ‘dream’ (97) is not used with this meaning. The nearest equivalent is bëgg lool ‘want very much’.

back_translation_en: ‘Wait until I put on other clothes!’
comms_internal: The transitive verb sol co-expresses ‘fill, stuff’ and ‘put on (a cloth)’.

sentence: naka lañu-y tudd-e garab g-ii ci wolof
glosses_en: how FocO/X.sI:3PL-INCPL be.named-CAUS tree(G) clG-DEM LOC wolof(B)
back_translation_en: ‘What’s the name of this tree in Wolof?’ lit. ‘How do they name this tree in Wolof?’
comms_internal: This is a transimpersonal construction (‘they call X Y’). The verb tudde is a causative verb derived from tudd ‘be named’, where the latter verb tudd can only be used for persons (as for example Denis laa tudd ‘My name is Denis’ lit. ‘I am named Denis’). The verbs tudd and tudde are cognate with the noun tur ‘name’, although synchronically, r ~ dd is not a productive pattern of consonant alternation. In the construction above, “the only term that behaves as an object in all respects is the person/thing whose name is given. For the name itself, I would prefer a label such as ‘pseudo-object’, because ‘second object’ suggests that this is a regular type of grammatical relation found with other verbs, which does not seem to be the case” (DC).

sentence: gaynde g-i song na rëbb b-i
glosses_en: lion(G) clG-DEF attack PRF.sI:3SG hunter(B) clB-DEF

sentence: dafa taw pax m-i sol-u ak ndox
glosses_en: FocV.sI:3SG rain hole(M) clM-DEF fill-MID with water(M)
back_translation_en: ‘It rained, and the hole filled with water.’
comms_internal: The intransitive verb solu ‘get filled with’ is a middle verb derived from sol ‘fill’ (and also ‘put on (a cloth)’, cf. 50). Further alternatives are fees used in the same SBJ_ak construction and feesal ‘fill’, a causative verb derived from intransitive fees ‘be/become full’, cf. “ndox m-i fees-al na pax m-i” [water(M) clM-DEF get.filled-CAUS PRF.sI:3SG hole(M) clM-DEF] ‘The water filled the hole.’ Interestingly, according to one of the consultants, in X solu ~ fees ak Y, the preposition can be dropped, the construction becoming thus at least superficially similar to a transitive construction.

sentence: fekk naa xale y-i sa kër nijaay
glosses_en: find PRF.sI:1SG child(B) clY-DEF POSS:2SG house(G) uncle(J)
back_translation_en: ‘I found the children at your uncle’s.’

comms_internal: Same as 42, same verb as 82.  The verb ñàkk ‘find’ is used transitively with the meanings ‘lack’ and ‘lose’ (cf. 42). Cf. also 82 ‘lose to someone’.
The transitive verb bañ is also used as an auxiliary with the meaning ‘refuse (to do something)’.

sentence: sa simiis b-i neex na ma
glosses_en: your shirt(B/Y) clB-DEF please PRF.sI:3SG oI:1SG
back_translation_en: ‘I like your shirt,’ lit. ‘Your shirt pleases me.’

sentence: a-y tund a léem dëkk b-i
glosses_en: INDEF-clY hill(W) FocS surround village(B) clB-DEF

comms_internal: The transitive verb dese ‘still have’ is cognate with the intransitive verb des ‘remain (somewhere)’, but this not a regular type of derivation in Wolof. Des can be found not only in a plain intransitive construction, but also in an impersonal construction with an expletive subject index and the NP referring to the person/thing that remains in postverbal construction, which is quite exceptional in Wolof.

sentence: bu ma jot-ee sa bataaxal dinaa la tontu
glosses_en: if sI:1SG receive-CPL POSS:2SG letter(B) FUT.sI:1SG oI:2SG answer
back_translation_en: ‘If I receive your letter, I’ll answer you.’

sentence: tijji naa bunt b-i ak caabi j-i
glosses_en: open PRF.sI:1SG door(B) clB-DEF with key(J) clJ-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘I opened the door with the key.’
comms_internal: Alternative is ubbi, also used as a transitive verb. These two verbs derive from ub ‘close’ and téj ‘close’.

back_translation_en: ‘The past is different from the present.’

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.

sentence: robb bii sama parfoŋ-u yaay la-y xeeñ
glosses_en: dress(B/Y) clB-DEM my perfume-of mother(J/Y) FocO-INCPL smell
back_translation_en: ‘This dress smells of my mother’s perfume.’
comms_internal: DC: it is difficult to decide whether it is really transitive, since the distinctive property of true transitive constructions is the possibility of indexing definite objects, and with this verb, the object is typically generic.

sentence: dama jàll dex g-i ak gaal
glosses_en: FocV.sI:1SG cross river(G) clG-DEF with boat(G)

sentence: naaj w-i a seey-al galaas g-i
glosses_en: sun(W) clW-DEF FocS melt-CAUS ice(G) clG-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘It was the sun that melted the ice.’
comms_internal: CAUS. The transitive verb seeyal is a causative verb deriving from intransitive seey.

sentence: kër g-i yell na ci nun
comms_internal: Alternative is the verb “jàpp” with the transitive pattern, as in “sa mbubb m-i jàpp na la” [POSS:2SG dress(M) clM-DEF suit PRF.sI:3SG oI:2SG] ‘Your dress suits you well.’. The reason for choosing this option is that it is intransitive and also the fact the alternative verb jàpp can also mean ‘catch’ (see 43).

Alternative is gental. The transitive verb wacc is the general way of expressing ‘abandon’. The transitive verb gental, used specifically for places, is a causative verb deriving from gent ‘get abandoned’.

sentence: muur naa màngo y-i ak músoor g-i
glosses_en: cover PRF.sI:1SG mango(B) clY-DEF with scarf(G) clG-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘I covered the mangoes with the scarf.’
comms_internal: Alternative is “sàng”, which is also a transitive verb.

sentence: maangi-y fàttali-ku bes b-a nu dajee foofa
glosses_en: sI:1SG.PRST-INCPL remind-MID day(B) clB-REL sI:1PL meet there
back_translation_en: I remember the day when we met there.’
comms_internal: The transitive verb fàattaliku ‘remember something’ is a middle verb derived from ditransitive fàttali ‘remind someone of something’. Fàttali and fàttaliku are cognate with fàtte ‘forget’, cf. 29.
Same as 93. Alternative is nànd. The verb nànd means specifically ‘understand’, whereas dégg also means ‘hear’.

sentence: mellax m-i dafa daanu ci kër g-i
glosses_en: lightning(M) clM-DEF FocV.sI:3SG fall LOC house(g) clG-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘The lightning hit the house,’ (lit. ‘The lightning fell on the house’).
comms_internal: Alternatives are “laal” with the TR pattern, cf. “dama sereti mu laal ko” [FocV.sI:1SG spit sI:3SG hit oI:3SG] ‘I spat and it fell on him.’ and “dal”, also with the TR pattern, cf. “ci tànk la xeer w-i dal Omar” [LOC leg(B) FocO/X.sI:3SG stone(W) sI:3SG hit PRN] ‘It was in the leg that the stone hit Omar.’ However, in the lighnting-and-house context, dal ‘hit’ (transitive) is still possible, but daanu ‘fall (intransitive) seems to be more usual.

Alternative is dagge, an applicative derivative used as transitive verb, cf. “lañset laa dagg-e” [razor(B) FocO/X.sI:1SG cut-APPL] ‘It was with a razor that I cut myself.’ The verb dagg ‘cut something’ / ‘cut oneself’ is ambitransitive. X dagg ak Y and X dagge Y express the same denotative meaning, but the applicative construction X dagge Y puts emphasis on the instrument, and is particularly usual if the instrument is explicitly focalized.

back_translation_en: ‘It was chewing gum that got stuck to his shoe.’

sentence: dama damyée ak Omar ak Sàmba ma gañe Omar wantee ma ñàkk ak Sàmba
glosses_en: FocV.sI:1SG play.checkers with PN and PN sI:1SG beat PN but sI:1SG lose and PN
back_translation_en: ‘I played checkers with Omar and Sàmba, I beat Omar but I lost to Sàmba.’
comms_internal: Same verb as 42 and 56, different pattern. Ñàkk is otherwise a transitive verb ‘lack’, cf. 56, or ‘lose something’, cf. 42. According to the consultants, in Wolof, X lost to Y is rather expressed as Y beat X with the verbs like gañe ~ dóor ~ duma ~ daan and the transitive pattern, cf. 13. The version given above was only suggested by one of the consultants.

sentence: dama bég ci seen defaroo b-i
glosses_en: FocV.sI:1SG rejoice LOC POSS:2PL reconciliation(B) clB-DEF
comms_internal: Same as 112. Alternative is “kontaan” (from French content) used in the same construction.

back_translation_en: ‘Go talk to Usmaan!’ lit. ‘Go converse with Usmaan!’

glosses_en: PN give birth PRF.sI:3SG five-CSTR.PL child(J)
comms_internal: The middle form of this verb (“juddu”) is the intransitive verb ‘be born’.
Alternative is waddal, also a transitive verb. The transitive verbs rotal and waddal are causative verbs derived from unaccusative intransitives rot ~ wadd ‘fall down’.
The transitive verb jiite is an applicative verb derived from intransitive jiit ‘be first’.
The transitive verb namm is also used as an auxiliary with the meaning ‘intend to do something’ (and as an auxiliary, it does not require the auxiliation marker ‑a).

sentence: golo g-i wàcc na garab g-i
glosses_en: monkey(G) clG-DEF get.down PRF.sI:3SG tree(G) clG-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘The monkey got down from the tree.’

comms_internal: The transitive verb déglu ‘listen’ can be decomposed as dég-l-u ‘make onself hear’: dégg is the transitive verb ‘hear’, ‑(a)l is a causative marker, and ‑u is a middle marker.
The transitive verb déggal can be viewed as a lexicalized applicative verb, cf. dégg ‘hear’ (93). The suffix ‑al is productively used both as a causative marker and an applicative marker.
Same as 78.

sentence: yëng-al ko ba soow m-i jaxas-oo ak lem g-i
glosses_en: stir oI:3SG until milk(M) clM-DEF mix-APPL.MID with honey(G) clG-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘Stir that until the milk get mixed with the honey!’
comms_internal: The transitive verb jaxas, synonymous with yëng, means ‘stir’. Jaxase is an applicative verb glossable as ‘stir something to mix it with something else’, and jaxasoo can be decomposed as jaxas-e-u, where ‑u is a middle marker (e + u > oo is a regular morphophonological process in Wolof).

back_translation_en: ‘Last night I dreamed about my mother.’
comms_internal: The lexeme gént can be used as a noun (‘dream’), an intransitive verb (‘have a dream’) or a transitive verb (‘dream about somone or something’).

sentence: Astu dafa d-oon xul-oo ak Bintu
glosses_en: PN FocV.sI:3SG ICPL-PST scold-RECP with PN

sentence: ñaata la sa montar b-i jar
glosses_en: how.much FocO/X.sI:3SG POSS:2SG watch(B) clB-DEF cost
comms_internal: The transitive verb jar ‘cost’ is also used as an auxiliary with the meaning ‘be worth being done’.

sentence: rëbbkat b-i diir na kéwél g-i waaye dafa ko moy
glosses_en: hunter(B) clB-DEF target PRF.sI:3SG antelope(G) clG-DEF but FocV.sI:3SG oI:3SG miss
back_translation_en: ‘The hunter targeted the antelope but he missed it.’
comms_internal: Alternatives are “X dóor Y sox” with the double-object construction “rëbbkat b-i dóor na sox kéwél g-i waaye dafa ko moy” [hunter(B) clB-DEF hit PRF.sI:3SG cartridge antelope(G) clG-DEF but FocV.sI:3SG oI:3SG miss] ‘The hunter shot at the antelope but he missed it.’, which literally means ‘X hit Y cartridge’ and “X soqi ci Y” with the SBJ_ci pattern and wehere soqi is an intransitive verb glossable as ‘fire a shot’, “rëbbkat b-i soqi na ci kéwél g-i waaye dafa ko moy” [hunter(B) clB-DEF fire.a.shot PRF.sI:3SG LOC antelope(G) clG-DEF but FocV.sI:3SG oI:3SG miss] ‘The hunter shot at the antelope but he missed it.’ Soqi is a reversive verb derived from sox ‘load (a gun)’. Denis’ impression is that diir is more frequent.

sentence: sotti nañu suuf ci ëtt b-i
glosses_en: pour PRF.sI:3PL sand(S) LOC yard(B) clB-DEF

sentence: gaal g-i angi-y suux ci dex g-i
glosses_en: boat(G) clG-DEF PRST-INCPL sink LOC river(G) clG-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘The boat is sinking in the river.’
comms_internal: Alternative is the verb diig with the same valency pattern.

sentence: gaynde g-i rey na rëbbkat b-i
glosses_en: lion(G) clG-DEF kill PRF.sI:3SG hunter(B) clB-DEF

back_translation_en: ‘It was you who hit the child.’

comms_internal: The transitive verb fóon co-expresses ‘kiss’ and ‘sniff’.
The transitive verb jàng co-expresses ‘read’ and ‘learn’.

sentence: ndax mën nga yëngal sa-y nopp
glosses_en: Q be.able PRF.sI:2SG move POSS:2SG-clY ear(B)
comms_internal: Same as 47. The verb pair yëngal ‘move (transitive)’ / yëngu ‘move (intransitive)’ is a case of equipollent derivation: ‑al is a causative suffix, ‑u is a middle suffix, but *yëng is not attested as a verb stem.

sentence: xale itam dañu ko war-a wormaal
glosses_en: child(B) too FocV.sI:3PL oI:3SG should-AUX respect
back_translation_en: ‘Children should be respected too,’ lit. ‘A child too, they should respect him.’
comms_internal: Alternative si weg, also a transitive verb. The verb wormaal derives from the noun worma ‘respect’ via suffixation of ‑al, mainly used in V>V derivation as a causative-applicative suffix.

Alternative is sàppi used in the same DO_SBJ pattern. Sappi is a reversive verb derived from saf ‘be tasty’. Génnaliku is probably cognate with génn ‘go out’, but cannot be analyzed as an instance of a regular derivation process.

sentence: sama doom dafa-y liggéey b-u baax ca ekkool b-a bég naa ci moom
glosses_en: POSS:1SG child(J) FocV.sI:3SG-INCPL work clB-REL be.good LOC.DIST school(B) clB-DEF.DIST be.satisfied PRF.sI:1SG LOC 3SG
back_translation_en: ‘My child does well at school, I am satisfied with him.’
comms_internal: Same as 83. Alternative is the synonymous verb kontaan used in the same valency pattern.

sentence: Sàmba dafa gis Astu rekk daldi ko-y nob
glosses_en: PN FocV.sI:3SG see PN as.soon.as start oI:3SG-INCPL love
back_translation_en: ‘As soon as Sàmba saw Astu, he fell in love with her,’ lit. ‘... he started loving her.’
comms_internal: CV. The verb nob is the transitive verb ‘love’ (see 46), daldi ‘start doing something’ is an auxiliary.

back_translation_en: ‘It’s only in you that I trust.’

sentence: dama yërëm Rama ndax doom-am j-i gaañu démb
glosses_en: FocV.sI:1SG symathize.with NPR because.of child(J)-POSS:3SG clJ-REL pass.away yesterday
back_translation_en: ‘I sympathize with Rama because of her child who passed away yesterday.’

sentence: Usmaan dafa ñee xarit-am ndax kër-am g-u bees g-i
glosses_en: PN FocV.sI:3SG envy friend(B)-POSS:3SG because of house(G)-POSS:3SG REL-clG be.new clG-DEF
back_translation_en: ‘Usmaan envies his friend because of his new house.’
‘Nobody should get angry with his friend.’
comms_internal: Same as 123. The transitive verb mere is an applicative verb derived from the intransitive verb mer ‘be angry’.
The intransitive verb waaru ‘be surprised’ is a middle verb derived from transitive waar ‘surprise’. The same meaning can be expressed by a construction with the verb “waar” and the DO_SBJ pattern.

sentence: waa Senegaal dañu bëgg ceeb-u jén
glosses_en: people PN FocV.sI:3PL like rice(B)-CSTR fish(W)
comms_internal: Same as 121. Alternative is “sopp”, which is also used in the transitive pattern. The transitive verb sopp ‘love’ is also used for persons (cf. 129). The basic meaning of the transitive verb bëgg is ‘wish’ (cf 121).

sentence: gannaaw bu ma liggéey-ee b-u baax dama-y bànneexoo àttaya j-u neex
glosses_en: after sI:1SG work-CPL clB-REL be.good FocV.sI:1SG-INCPL rejoice.APPL tea(J) clJ-REL be.pleasant
back_translation_en: ‘After having worked well, I enjoy a good tea.’
comms_internal: The transitive verb bànneexoo, decomposable as bànneex-u-e, is an applicative verb derived from bànneexu. Alternatives are 1) “féexloo” with the TR pattern, cf. “gannaaw bu ma liggéey-ee b-u baax dama-y feex-loo àttaya j-u neex” [after sI:1SG work-CPL clB-REL be.good FocV.sI:1SG-INCPL be.at.ease-CAUS.MID.APPL tea(J) clJ-REL be.pleasant] ‘After having worked well, I enjoy a good tea.’ and 2) “xéewalu” with the SBJ_ci pattern. “gannaaw bu ma liggéey-ee b-u baax dama-y xééwal-u àttaya j-u neex” [after sI:1SG work-CPL clB-REL be.good FocV.sI:1SG-INCPL make.a.present.to.MID tea(J) clJ-REL be.pleasant] ‘After having worked well, I enjoy a good tea.’ Bànneex ‘pleasure, happiness’ is a noun, from which the intransitive verb bànneexu ‘rejoice’ is formed via suffixation of ‑u, mostly used as a middle suffix in V>V derivation. The transitive verb féexloo ‘enjoy’can be decomposed as féex-al-u-e ‘make oneself be at ease by means of’: feex is an intransitive verb ‘be at ease’, ‑al is a causative suffix, ‑u is a middle suffix, and ‑e is an applicative suffix.
Same as 119.

sentence: Usmaan dafa ma mer-e ndax dama diiŋat doom-am
glosses_en: PN FocV.sI:3SG oI:1SG get.angry-APPL because FocV.sI:1SG criticize child(J)-POSS:3SG
back_translation_en: ‘Usmaan took offence at me because I criticized his child.’
comms_internal: Same as 117. The transitive verb mere is an applicative verb derived from intransitive mer ‘get angry’.

The transitive verb naqadi is cognate with the intransitive verb neex ‘be pleasant’. In fact, this verb is typically used with inanimate / eventive subjects, cf. Denis’ comment: “As usual in West African languages, speakers are reluctant to use human subjects in this context, they prefer formulations that are literally ‘What you did / what you said / the way you behaved, etc. made me sad’, as for example: “li nga def moo ma naqadi” [what sI:2SG do FocS.sI:3SG oI:1SG make.sad]. naqadi lit. ‘be unpleasant (for someone)’ derives from neex ‘be pleasant (for someone)’ (‑adi is a negative suffix which triggers here an irregular modification of the stem to which it attaches).

sentence: bés b-u nekk ma yéem-u ci mbir-u Yàlla
glosses_en: day(B) clB-REL exist sI:1SG amaze-MID LOC work(M)-CSTR God
back_translation_en: ‘Every day I marvel at the work of God.’
comms_internal: The intransitive verb yéemu is a middle verb derived from transitive yéem ‘amaze’.

sentence: sa jabar j-i dafa la jéppi
glosses_en: POSS:2SG wife(J) clJ-DEF FocV.sI:3SG oI:2SG despise
comms_internal: Alternative is “sib”, which is also a transitive verb.

The intransitive verb jaaxle ‘worry (intr.)’ ‘derives from transitive jaaxal ‘worry (tr.)’. However, this is not a synchronically regular derivation, since normally, middle verbs are derived by means of the suffix ‑u. Comparative data suggest that, historically, this may be a vestige of a former passive derivation that has ceased to be productive in Wolof.
The verb xoñoñ is an ambitransitive verb expressing the meaning ‘irritate, exasperate’ in its transitive use, and ‘get irritated / exasperated’ in its intransitive use.
Cf. also 119.

back_translation_en: ‘Usmaan is ashamed of his small stature.’
comms_internal: Alternative is the derived causative verb rusloo, which is used in the DO_SBJ pattern.
